description: Supermarkets, including Sainsbury's where the issue was first reported, have withdrawn houmous products due to a 'taste' problem. Now fans are debating whether to spell it houmous or hummus.
title: Social media debates how you should really spell houmous
title_page: Social media debates how you should really spell houmous | Daily Mail Online
text:
Yesterday British shoppers were sent into a frenzy after it was announced several UK supermarkets would be withdrawing nearly all its houmous products from shelves due to a 'taste issue'.
But after thousands exchanged hilarious messages online jokingly expressing their horror at the so-called houmous crisis, fans of the chickpea dip are now debating the correct way to spell it.
Sainsbury's uses the spelling 'houmous' for all its products, which have been withdrawn from shelves for at least another day after some shoppers complained the dip tasted 'fizzy' and 'like plastic'.
And now reports have emerged that other supermarkets including Tesco and M&S have also been affected by the 'production issue,' which is being investigated with suppliers.
Sainsbury's houmous products - including its normal houmous and its reduced fat version of the dip - were withdrawn this week after customers complained about the taste and it has affected other supermarkets too
The most common spelling is in fact 'hummus' - though other variations such as houmus, hoummos, and humus are also in use.
But which spelling is right?
Many experts believe that 'hummus' is in fact the most accurate spelling of the chickpea and tahini dip's name.
That's because it's the closest to the Arabic translation for the word, as the full name for houmous is 'hummus bi tahini' which literally means 'chickpeas with tahini'.
Dozens of people invested in the so-called houmous crisis - which has inspired thousands of hilarious jokes comparing the withdrawal of products from Sainsbury's to a catastrophe - are now debating the correct way to spell the name of the chickpea dip
The Guardian style guide - which many people use as a definitive guide on spellings and grammar - also declares the word is spelled 'hummus'.
But 'houmous' is common enough in British parlance to be listed in UK dictionaries as an approved alternative spelling.
Most major supermarkets use this spelling for their houmous products as generally it is the favoured way to spell the word in British English. In American English, 'hummus' is almost always used.
Social media users have been tweeting furiously about the Sainsbury's houmous crisis, after the supermarket was forced to withdraw many of its products due to a 'taste' issue
Dozens of people have been tweeting about the lack of houmous at Sainsbury's stores across the country, jokingly comparing it to a 'catastrophe'
But in the end, both spellings are technically correct - making it confusing for fans of the dip.
Sainsbury's said in a statement yesterday that it hopes the withdrawn products will return to shelves by tomorrow.
MailOnline has asked the supermarket for an update.
M&S told The Telegraph yesterday: 'Some of our houmous products were temporarily taken off shelf due to a supplier issue. We can reassure customers that our recipe hasnâ€™t changed and that houmous is now back in store.'
